Key Arguments: The legislation contravenes the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, particularly Article 19, which upholds freedom of expression.
The Australian Human Rights Commission warns against any body being the sole arbiter of truth.
The legislation exempts government communications, creating unequal laws for government and citizens.
It could suppress diverse perspectives and hinder the free flow of information.
It poses a threat to independent journalism and could lead to government control or censorship.
It infringes on the public's right to know and limits access to information.
It could hinder societal progress by stifling creativity and innovation.
There is potential for abuse of power by authorities to control information and suppress dissent.
It contradicts international obligations under the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
Notable Quotes: Any legislation limiting free speech in the media would contravene the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights, particularly Article 19.
The Australian Human Rights Commission has warned against giving any body the power to be 'the sole arbiter of truth'.
Legislation that restricts free speech in the media may lead to government control or censorship, eroding the independence of journalism.
